title: 103_hr2220
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom of Speech on Campus Act of 1993". The Congress recognizes free speech as a fundamental right and safeguard against tyranny, emphasizing the importance of intellectual freedom and the free exchange of ideas in universities. Members of the university have an obligation to permit free expression to fulfill the institution's function. Some universities are using Federal funds to impose prior restraints on speech, such as behavior codes and harassment policies that stifle unpopular viewpoints. The sense of Congress is that students at federally funded universities should have freedom of speech on campus without interference. Title IX is amended to prohibit discrimination based on protected speech. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits discrimination against students based on protected speech at federally funded institutions, with exceptions for religious and military institutions. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits discrimination against students based on protected speech at federally funded institutions, with exceptions for religious and military institutions. The act allows for official sanctions on students who disrupt lectures or classes, and institutions can take actions to ensure safety, protect property, and maintain academic continuity. The term 'protected speech' refers to speech protected under the first and fourteenth amendments of the US Constitution at institutions of higher education. Official sanctions include expulsion, suspension, and other disciplinary actions. The term 'protected speech' at institutions of higher education includes disciplinary actions such as warnings and official sanctions like expulsion or suspension. Federal administrative enforcement under Section 902 of the Education Amendments of 1972 is amended to include new provisions.
